column1: Maryville is the second largest city (first is St. Joseph
column2: Missouri) wholly within the boundaries of the 1836 Platte Purchase which expanded Missouri's borders into former Indian Territory in northwest Missouri.
1845.Maryville's name originates from the town's first postmaster
column3: Amos Graham. Graham was one of the original settlers of what would later become downtown Maryville
column4: and the city was named after his wife
column5: Mary. In addition to his above historical role
column6: Graham was also one of the original Nodaway County Commissioners and served as the first county clerk when the county was formally organized in 1845.  Maryville
column7: which is near the geographic center of Nodaway County
column8: was also named the county seat in the same year.The first house in Maryville was built by Jack (John) Saunders

column12: the second of only three in the city's history. The current courthouse was built in 1881 with a design by Edmond Jacques Eckel and George R. Mann. Mann would later go on to design the Arkansas State Capitol. The courthouse is currently listed on the National Register of Historic Places and is adorned with a sculpture of a pineapple
column13: the sign of welcome.  The original court complex included one of the country's only rotary jails. The jail was torn down in 1984 and replaced with a new structure on the same site.The city was incorporated in 1856

column22: Burlington and Quincy Railroad) arrived.  The Wabash Railroad arrived in 1879. Both railroads no longer operate in the city and no railroads are operated anywhere in Nodaway County.

column1: In 1872 Albert P. Morehouse started the Nodaway Democrat
column2: which became the Maryville Daily Forum.  Morehouse would become governor.  He lived in a house on Vine Street.  Coincidentally
column3: the house would later be occupied by Forrest C. Donnell before Donnell became a governor and U.S. Senator.  The Forum was a chain-owned newspaper for nearly 100 years and in 2013 it reverted to local ownership by the Cobb Group.In 1889 the Maryville Methodist Seminary opened.

column1: In 1891 Elizabeth Howell (who operated Howell Millinery in Maryville) contributed to the development of the Lazy Susan when she received an American patent for "certain new and useful Improvements in Self-Waiting Tables". Howell's device ran more smoothly and did not permit crumbs to fall into the space between the Lazy Susan and the table.In 1894 Mary Augustine Giesen moved to Maryville and opened St. Francis Hospital.

column2: the horse Elwood was foaled at Faustiana Farms
column3: owned by Mrs. J.B. Prather
column4: on the west side of Maryville. It won the Kentucky Derby in 1904 and was the first Derby winner to be bred by a woman. Faustiana was located where the Maryville Country Club is today. Mrs. Prather also has connections with the second horse to be owned and bred by a woman to win the Derby – Black Gold in 1924
column5: which was the great grandchild of Faustus
column6: the namesake of the Faustiana farm. Elwood and Black Gold are two of 10 Kentucky Derby winners with Nodaway County connections. Trainer Ben A. Jones won the Derby in 1938
column10: 1949 and 1952. His son Jimmy Jones won in 1957 and 1958. They operated a horse farm at Parnell
column11: Missouri until their deaths (although their racing fame is tied to Calumet Farm in Kentucky).  Memorabilia from their horse racing days are St. Francis Hospital and at the Nodaway County Historical Society Museum.

column2: Maryville won a contest to get the Fifth District Normal School

column6: to the state. The college was on the northwest corner of the city
column7: nearly adjoining the Wabash train station. The most significant structure on the land transferred to the state was the Thomas Gaunt mansion
column8: which is also on the National Register and is the college President's residence. Gaunt owned an extensive nursery on his property

column1: In 1928 there was speculation that Maryville would become the "Western White House" for Herbert Hoover when it was discovered that he owned a farm 15 miles south of town.  The farm was actually only 80 acres and he had acquired it after holding the mortgage for his Stanford University Class of 1895 roommate Samuel Wilson Collins.  It was Iowa-native Hoover's only farm and Hoover visited it in 1933 after leaving office.  He was accompanied by his former Secretary of Agriculture Arthur M. Hyde. Hoover's vice president Charles Curtis visited Maryville on October 4
column2: 1932 where spoke at the Administration Building after being rained out of a planned appearance at the Courthouse.

column1: Harry S. Truman (along with Bess and Margaret Truman) made the last of several visits to Maryville on August 3
column2: 1962 when he dedicated the current post office. Truman had extensive ties to Maryville.  During World War I Truman was a member of the 129th Field Artillery Regiment in the Missouri National Guard
column3: which is headquartered in Maryville. Truman commanded Battery D in the war of the 129th. The 129th official motto is "Truman's Own" because of the affiliation. During the Meuse-Argonne Offensive during World War I in 1918
column6: I'm where I want to be – in command of this battery. I'd rather be here than president of the United States." Among the original 129th soldiers was Edward V. Condon (1893–1974) who later operated the Condon Corner Drug Store across the street on the Square after the war. Truman dedicated the 129th's armory on the northwest side of Bearcat Stadium on the college campus on February 20
column7: 1955.The 1955 armory was repurposed as the Jon T. Rickman Electronic Campus Support Center in 2003
column8: when a new armory was built further west of the campus near the Maryville Country Club
column9: which is the site of the original Faustiana Farm complex. Many of Maryville's most active citizens have ties to the 129th

column19: the Palms Bar in town began sponsoring the "World's Shortest Saint Patrick's Day Parade." The parades
column20: which are less than a block long
column21: have been getting shorter each year as other towns compete for the title. One of the mainstays of events has been a garbage truck driving down the street at the beginning
column22: pouring out buckets of green water as a Maryville homage to the dyeing of the Chicago River green. In 2015
column23: the parade moved from being a block off the square to actually being on the square after it became sponsored by Burny's Sports Bar.In 1994
column24: Mozingo Lake opened east of Maryville. Its Mozingo Lake Golf Course has courses designed by Donald Sechrest and Tom Watson (which opened in 2016).In 1996

column1: Maryville became a football powerhouse in 1994 when Mel Tjeerdsma became coach of Northwest Missouri State Bearcats football.  The Bearcats played in 1998
column9: 2015 and 2016 NCAA Division II Football Championship games winning in 1998
column13: 2015 and 2016. The basketball team won another national title in the NCAA Division II Basketball Championship in 2017. In addition the Maryville High School football team appeared in 1996
column21: in addition to an earlier championship in 1982) state championship games.  The dual championships have earned the town nickname of "Title Town." The high school has the unique mascot of "Spoofhounds."  Both schools have green and white for their school colors. Adam Dorrel
column23: succeeded his former boss Tjeerdsma when he retired as coach in 2010 and kept up the tradition winning the national titles in 2013

column2: a notorious lynching occurred in Maryville when a mob of 2
column4: 000 people burned alive African American Raymond Gunn
column6: charged with the attempted rape and killing of a 20-year-old white school teacher
column7: to which he intended to plead not guilty. One woman held her young girl up so the girl could get a better view of the naked man afire. A Maryville policeman directed traffic as Gunn burned. After the fire was out
column8: hundreds of the mob poked around in his ashes for souvenirs
column9: with the pieces of his charred remains and teeth and bone fragments divided among them. While the Sheriff said he knew who had committed the killing
column10: nobody was ever charged.The lynching attracted national attention and was frequently invoked in the unsuccessful campaign to pass the Costigan-Wagner Bill
column11: which would have made it a federal crime for law enforcement officials to refuse to try to prevent a lynching.

column1: A controversial case arose in 2012 when Matthew Barnett
column3: was arrested for the rape and sexual assault of a 14-year-old girl. A 15-year-old boy was accused of doing the same to the girl’s 13-year-old friend
column4: and a third boy admitted to recording Barnett's alleged assault on a cellphone. A significant controversy arose in 2013 when the county prosecutor dropped felony and misdemeanor charges against Barnett
column5: grandson of influential former state representative Rex Barnett
column6: and the Nodaway County prosecutor dropped the felony sexual exploitation charge against the third boy.The victim was relentlessly bullied and harassed
column7: she first attempted suicide when she was 16 years old. Outrage in online communities soon followed when the story surrounding this case was revisited in October 2013. In 2014
column8: a special prosecutor was put in charge to reinvestigate the case. Barnett pleaded guilty to misdemeanor second-degree endangerment of the welfare of a child for leaving her outside her house
column9: and was sentenced by Missouri Circuit Judge Glen Dietrich to four months in jail that were suspended in favor of two years probation. Barnett was sentenced in juvenile court for the assault. The incident is featured in the 2016 Netflix documentary Audrie & Daisy.

column1: Situated in a transitional climate area
column2: Maryville has a humid continental climate (Köppen climate classification Dfa) with hot
column3: humid summers combined with unusually cold winters by Missouri standards. Although prone to hard freezes
column4: Maryville's coldest month of January still retains average highs above the freezing point. The large diurnal temperature variations plunge average lows into the mid-teens
column5: with around 141 air frosts per year on average.

column1: The city of Maryville is governed by a city council consisting of five members who are elected at-large and serve terms of three years.  There is no limit to the number of terms that one can serve on the council.  Each year
column2: one of the council members is selected to serve as the mayor of the city and another as the mayor pro tem.

column1: There are two U.S. Highways in Maryville: U.S. Routes 71 and 136 intersect on the eastern side of the city. A branch of US 71
column3: serves as the main street for the city. Route 46
column5: and Route V also provide access outside the city. In 2002
column7: |U.S. 71 was converted to a four-lane route from Savannah and a bypass was built along the east side of Maryville. Route 71 is at least a four-lane and some cases an interstate highway for the entire length of Missouri
column8: from the Arkansas border and there had been considerable delays in converting the last remaining two-lane section from Savannah to Maryville. US 71 north of Maryville to the Iowa border is the only remaining two-lane portion of Route 71 in Missouri.Maryville is served by the Northwest Missouri Regional Airport
column9: which is a general aviation airport with no commercial service.
